body: Note that there's no valid `'a` lifetime for the `OwningPtr`, in fact `'a` is not used in the inputs at all. This might work with a callback API though.

issue.title: Design and implement a full-fledged undo-redo system

labels.name: S-Needs-Design-Doc

labels.name: A-Undo
labels.description: Related to undo/redo logic or bevy_undo crate

issue.body:
[10:34 PM]Alice ðŸŒ¹: I think that there's a lot of interesting and important complexity to tackle with undoing, and I really like the contextual / nested undo-redo  + a trait based approach
[10:34 PM]Alice ðŸŒ¹: But for now, a relatively simple trait will do
[10:36 PM]Alice ðŸŒ¹: I'd also like to lean away from a snapshot-based approach if possible, and avoid a distinct storage (sorry @nth but I've worked with this and I found it very frustrating)
[10:36 PM]Alice ðŸŒ¹: There's definitely a chance that we can't make that sort of design work, but I'm happy to cross that bridge when we get there

This is a followup to #2, which is a simple design to get us started.

Cross-posted from [Discord](https://discordapp.com/channels/691052431525675048/789987800014651412/1287602981201645589).

body:
I took the liberty to rewrite parts of the initial comment to focus on the "move component from one entity to another" solution. The "return some blob data for later reinsertion" seems just not attractive to me while the first might be interesting for other use cases as well, also to be implemented for `EntityCommands`

I hope this brings the remaining design work forward.

issue.title: Extend cloning functionality and add convenience methods to `EntityWorldMut` and `EntityCommands`

labels.name: C-Usability
labels.description: A targeted quality-of-life change that makes Bevy easier to use

labels.name: M-Release-Note
labels.description: Work that should be called out in the blog due to impact

labels.name: S-Waiting-on-Author
labels.description: The author needs to make changes or address concerns before this can be merged

repository.name: bevy
repository.description: A refreshingly simple data-driven game engine built in Rust

issue.body:
## Objective

Thanks to @eugineerd's work on entity cloning (#16132), we now have a robust way to copy components between entities. We can extend this to implement some useful functionality that would have been more complicated before.

Closes #15350.

## Solution

`EntityCloneBuilder` now automatically includes required components alongside any component added to or removed from the component filter.

Added the following methods to `EntityCloneBuilder`:
- **`move_components`**
  - Syntax: `move_components(&mut self, enable: bool)`
  - Enables/disables removing the components from the original entity at the end of the cloning process, effectively moving them to the target entity.
- **`without_required_components`**
  - Syntax: `without_required_components(&mut self, builder: impl FnOnce(&mut EntityCloneBuilder))`
  - Opens a scope where any components added to or removed from the filter will not automatically involve those components' required components.

Added the following methods to `EntityWorldMut` and `EntityCommands`:
- **`clone_with`**
  - Syntax: `clone_with(&mut self, target: Entity, config: impl FnOnce(&mut EntityCloneBuilder))`
  - Easy access to `EntityCloneBuilder`.
- **`clone_components`**
  - Syntax: `clone_components::<B: Bundle>(&mut self, target: Entity)`
  - Shortcut if you just want to clone components with default settings.
- **`move_components`**
  - Syntax: `move_components::<B: Bundle>(&mut self, target: Entity)`
  - Shortcut if you want to move components with otherwise default settings.

Also added `clone_and_spawn` and `clone_and_spawn_with` to `EntityWorldMut` (`EntityCommands` already had them).

## Showcase

```
assert_eq!(world.entity(entity_a).get::<ComponentA>(), Some(&ComponentA(1)));
assert_eq!(world.entity(entity_b).get::<ComponentA>(), None);
world.entity_mut(entity_a).clone_components::<ComponentA>(entity_b);
assert_eq!(world.entity(entity_a).get::<ComponentA>(), Some(&ComponentA(1)));
assert_eq!(world.entity(entity_b).get::<ComponentA>(), Some(&ComponentA(1)));

assert_eq!(world.entity(entity_a).get::<ComponentB>(), Some(&ComponentB(2)));
assert_eq!(world.entity(entity_b).get::<ComponentB>(), None);
world.entity_mut(entity_a).move_components::<ComponentB>(entity_b);
assert_eq!(world.entity(entity_a).get::<ComponentB>(), None);
assert_eq!(world.entity(entity_b).get::<ComponentB>(), Some(&ComponentB(2)));
```

body:
@alice-i-cecile This issue was closed as completed in #16826, but without the untyped variants (for example `move_by_ids`) only part of what the issue was about was done.

When I want to make reversible commands, I need to be sensitive about which components already exist, which are added additionally by the required-component feature and so on. I don't think I can do that solely with `Bundle` as the parameter.

For example:
- Entity 1 has components `A` and `B`
- Entity 2 has component `A`

The user want to move `A` and `B` from 1 to 2 by using the bundle `(A, B)` as the generic parameter.
To make this reversible I need to backup `A` at entity 2 by moving that to some third entity.
But I only have the `(A, B)` bundle type and there is no "move component `A` by the `ComponentId` N from 2 to 3" in the API of #16826. If I instead try to move `(A, B)` from 2 to 3 this would fail because there is no `B` at entity 2.

Could this be reopened or should I write a new issue that focuses on this?
